hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Law Bans Using Internet As a Lure

body.head.byline: By Jessica Bruder (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

abstract.p: New Jersey Acting Governor Richard J Codey signs law making it illegal to lure someone over the Internet to commit crime; adult luring will be punishable by maximum of five years in prison and $15,000 fine (S)

block.p: A bill to make it illegal to lure someone over the Internet to commit a crime has been signed into law by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey. The bill, signed Monday, followed a case in 2002 in which a stranger menaced Patricia Barteck of Wood-Ridge after reading her address in an Internet chat room. Her cousin, Jonathan Gilberti, was convicted of posing as Ms. Barteck on the Internet, where he had posted her home address and added an explicit sexual invitation. Adult luring, as defined in the new law, will be punishable by a maximum of five years in prison and a $15,000 fine.
